awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Imaging and Mechanics-based Projects on Accidental Cases of Trauma (IMPACT)
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site: Imaging and Mechanics-based Projects on Accidental Cases of Trauma (IMPACT) at Wake Forest University School of Medicine (WFSM) offers multidisciplinary biomedical engineering opportunities aimed to improve the fundamental understanding of trauma and injury. Aligned with their vision to build a diverse and robust STEM workforce training program, objectives emphasize training, educating, mentoring, and inspiring underrepresented students to pursue biomedical research and careers. Students, including those from underrepresented groups, will gain a fundamental understanding of injury research, develop critical thinking skills to grow as independent researchers, and be encouraged to pursue educational and career opportunities in biomedical research. The REU research will benefit society through development of predictive models for injury; advancements to military, automotive, sports, and spaceflight safety; and improvements to diagnostic and therapeutic approaches to prevent, mitigate, and treat injuries and associated sequela. Research findings will be disseminated via video snapshots, publications, conference abstracts, presentations, patents, and reports authored by REU students, with the goal of promoting STEM research and careers to hundreds of students who attend the summer symposium, visit the website, or interface with the REU students presenting at national conferences and their undergraduate colleges.

The goals of the ten-week summer REU program are to (1) Offer biomedical engineering research training to students, and teach them medical imaging and biomechanics techniques, which they will apply to investigate mechanistic, physiological, anatomical, and other fundamental factors related to accidental trauma; (2) Educate students on the research process, research ethics, dissemination of findings through publication and presentation, and the societal implications of their research, through hands-on training paired with seminars focusing on biomedical research and professional development topics; (3) Cultivate mentoring relationships between REU participants, graduate students and faculty mentors that extend beyond the duration of the REU, providing support, guidance, and encouragement to the REU participants as they develop into more confident and independent scientific researchers; and (4) Foster an interest in biomedical engineering research within underrepresented groups and students with limited opportunities for STEM research, which will impact the career plans of the REU participants, and hundreds of students reached through the program's widespread dissemination campaign.  Each summer, 12 REU participants will receive hands-on research training that encourages them to make creative contributions to research projects culminating in the dissemination of their work in the form of a podium presentation at the end-of-summer symposium, and a poster presentation at a national conference. The intended impact of the REU site is to impart training on engineering research and the research process, cultivate lasting mentoring relationships, and foster an interest in STEM research and higher education in the REU students and the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under this REU award, Wake Forest University School of Medicine (WFUSM) provided research opportunities for 37 undergraduate participants in the field of biomedical engineering. This program introduced students to injury research, fostering the development of new ideas and engineering solutions to treat and manage injuries. The REU program involved collaborations across several disciplines, including Biomedical Engineering, Health & Exercise Science, Orthopedics, Radiology, and Radiation Oncology. Students were trained in essential imaging and biomechanical techniques they applied to injury research. The program immersed participants in trauma research, offering hands-on training, complex problem-solving, and opportunities for scientific presentation and communication. The primary goal was for each participant to contribute to a research project by developing new skills and understanding how their research could play a role in preventing, addressing, and enhancing the scientific knowledge of injuries.

To achieve our four main objectives:

  1. Faculty mentors provided direct research training in biomedical engineering, focusing on exploring mechanistic, physiological, anatomical, and other key factors related to injuries.
  2. Students learned about the research process, ethical considerations, scientific communication, and societal impacts through their mentored research experience, educational seminars, and student authorship of conference abstracts, poster presentations, and journal articles.
  3. Daily mentorship from faculty and graduate students helped participants grow into more independent researchers, building their knowledge, confidence, and ability to make creative contributions to their projects.
  4. The program offered biomedical engineering research opportunities to 37 students, including students attending colleges with limited opportunities for STEM undergraduate research.

The intellectual focus of the IMPACT REU Site was on multidisciplinary engineering research in medical imaging and biomechanics, aimed at investigating the underlying mechanistic, physiological, anatomical, and other fundamental aspects of injuries. Students were trained to apply their engineering and research skills to influence real-world safety regulations, clinical practices, and overall quality of life for trauma victims.

The educational focus involved hands-on research, training boot camps, and professional development, encouraging participants to transition from a dependent role to a more independent researcher. As students gained knowledge, built confidence, and contributed creatively to their projects, their skills in the laboratory, writing, communication, and career development were all enhanced through the REU experience.

Research Projects: Each summer, the REU offered a range of multidisciplinary projects focused on imaging and mechanics in the study of injury. These projects were designed to immerse participants in the research process, from conducting literature reviews and forming hypotheses to testing and analyzing results to assess their hypotheses. Mentors worked with participants to gradually foster independence, providing numerous opportunities for students to make significant contributions to their research.

End-of-summer REU Symposium: On the final day of the program, each participant delivered a brief podium presentation on their research at the REU Symposium, which was held at the Biotech Place Conference Center. The event was attended by over 75 faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates.

Participant Outcomes: More than 90% of participants reported that the research experience met or exceeded their expectations, and they found it far more effective than traditional classroom-based learning. Over 70% of students said the program increased their interest in pursuing graduate school. Many participants have continued their education at top universities nationwide, with several returning to pursue graduate studies in our biomedical engineering program. This data highlights the REU's success in sparking interest in biomedical research and graduate education.

Research Products: In total, this REU cohort delivered 37 podium presentations at our REU Symposium. Each student had the opportunity to submit an abstract to the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) Annual Meeting, and 32 (86%) of REU participants presented their research at this conference. The collective research efforts of the REU students also led to first authorships, co-authorships, and acknowledgements in journal articles.

Broader Impacts: The REU program emphasized imaging and mechanics-based research techniques, with the ultimate goal of improving the prevention, treatment, and scientific understanding of injuries. The students' projects had societal benefits, including the development of injury prediction models, advancements in sports and automotive safety, and improvements to diagnostic and therapeutic methods for preventing and treating injuries. The program successfully prepared students to continue their STEM research careers and contributed to the dissemination of research findings to the broader community.
